current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To ensure that employers cannot interfere in their employees’ birth control and other health care
			 decisions.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read the first time

action-desc.#text: Read the second time and placed on the calendar
Read the second time and placed on the calendar

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Protect Women's Health From Corporate Interference Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Protect Women's Health From Corporate Interference Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

The purpose of this Act is to ensure that
			 employers that provide health benefits to their
			 employees cannot deny any specific health benefits, including
			 contraception
			 coverage, to any of their employees or the covered
			 dependents of such employees entitled by Federal law to receive such
			 coverage.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds as follows:

text.#text:
Access to the full range of health benefits and preventive services, as guaranteed under Federal
			 law or through Federal regulations, provides all Americans with the
			 opportunity to lead healthier and more productive lives.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
declared it one of the Ten Great Public
			 Health
			 Achievements of the 20th Century.  While the most common reason women use
			 contraception is to prevent pregnancy, 58 percent of oral contraceptive
			 users cite noncontraceptive health benefits as reasons for using the
			 method.  Fourteen percent of birth control pill users, more than 1,500,000
			 women, rely on birth control pills for noncontraceptive purposes only.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Centers
			 for Disease Control and Prevention

text.#text:
Birth control is a critical health care service for women.  Ninety-nine percent of sexually active
			 women use birth control at least once in their lifetimes, and the

In addition to providing health benefits for women, access to birth control has been directly
			 connected to women’s economic success and ability to participate in
			 society equally.  Women with access to birth control are more likely to
			 have higher educational achievement and career achievement, and to be paid
			 higher wages.

The independent, nonprofit Institute of Medicine recommends, as part of its recommended
			 preventive health measures, that women’s preventive health be covered
			 by health plans with no cost-sharing to promote optimal health of
			 women.  The Institute of Medicine noted that the contraceptive methods
			 recommendation was one of the most important recommendations for women.

Affordability has long been a barrier to women being able to use birth control and other preventive
			 health services effectively.  A national survey of women who were
			 currently using some form of contraception found that one-third  would
			 switch to a different method of contraception if they did not have to
			 worry about cost. 
			 Women citing cost concerns were twice as likely as other women to rely on
			 less effective methods of contraception.

Three separate studies have found that lack of
			 health coverage is significantly associated with reduced use of
			 prescription
			 contraceptives.

Cost-sharing requirements can dramatically reduce the use of preventive health care measures,
			 particularly among lower-income women.  Studies have shown that
			 eliminating cost-sharing for the most effective forms of contraception
			 (intrauterine devices, implants, and injectables) leads to sizable
			 increases in the use of these methods.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and related education and counseling, as prescribed by a
			 health care provider.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
sought to remove the barrier to
			 care by requiring all new health plans to
			 cover recommended preventive services without cost-sharing, which include
			 women’s preventative services.  These services include all
			 methods of
			 contraception and sterilization approved by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act

text.#text:
The contraceptive coverage provision has been a success in increasing access to this critical
			 health service for women. As of 2013, 47,000,000 women were covered by
			 this requirement.	Women have saved $483,000,000 in out-of-pocket
			 costs for oral
			 contraceptives with no copayments in 2013 compared to 2012.

The Journal of the American Medical Association reports that 7 out of 10 people in the United
			 States support coverage of contraception, with significantly
			 higher support among women, Hispanic Americans, and Black Americans.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
.  A total of 48,500,000 women are estimated to benefit
			 from preventive services coverage without cost-sharing.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Patient Protection and
			 Affordable Care Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act

text.#text:
An estimated 76,000,000 people in the United States, including 30,000,000 women, are newly eligible
			 for expanded preventive services coverage under the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
be available in order to ensure that each woman, in
			 consultation with her medical provider, can make appropriate decisions
			 about her health care.

text.#text:
The most appropriate method of contraception varies according to each individual woman’s needs and
			 medical history.  Women may have medical contraindications and thus not be
			 able to use certain types of contraceptive methods.  It is therefore vital
			 that the full range of contraceptive methods approved by the

Covering proven preventative services like contraception lowers health care spending as it improves
			 health.  The Federal Government experienced no increase in costs at all
			 after it began covering
			 contraceptives for Federal employees.	A study by the National Business
			 Group on Health estimated that it costs employers 15 to 17 percent more to
			 not provide contraceptive coverage in employee health plans, accounting
			 for the employer’s direct medical costs of pregnancy and indirect costs
			 related to employee absence and reduced productivity.

Dozens of
			 cases have been filed in Federal court by employers that want to take this
			 benefit away from their employees and the covered dependents of such
			 employees.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
held, in Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, Inc. and Conestoga 
			 Wood Specialties Corp. v. Burwell, that some for-profit corporations can
			 take away the
			 birth control coverage guaranteed to their
			 employees and the covered dependents of such employees through their group
			 health plan.

text.#text: On June 30, 2014, the

quote.#tail:
Justice Ginsburg also notes that the decision opens up the door to religiously grounded employer
			 objections to a whole host of health care services like

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: would otherwise secure.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act

quote.#text:
decision of startling breadth … the exemption sought by Hobby Lobby and Conestoga … would deny
			 legions of women who do not hold their employers’ beliefs access to
			 contraceptive coverage that the

blood transfusions …. antidepressants … medications derived from pigs, including anesthesia … and
			 vaccinations.

text.#text: In a dissent in those cases, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg states that in this

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
’s decision in those cases allows employers, that otherwise provide coverage of
			 preventive health services, to deny their employees and the covered
			 dependents of such employees contraceptive coverage
			 and to treat a critical women’s health service differently than other
			 comparable services.  Legislation is needed to clarify that employers may
			 not discriminate against their employees and dependents.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
act to reinstate contraception
			 coverage and to protect employees and the covered dependents of such
			 employees from other attempts to take
			 away coverage for other health benefits to which such employees and
			 dependents are entitled under Federal law.

text.#text: It is imperative that

This Act is intended to
			 be consistent with the Congressional intent in enacting the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, and with the exemption for
			 houses of worship, and an accommodation for religiously-affiliated
			 nonprofit organizations with objections to contraceptive coverage.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Religious
			 Freedom and
			 Restoration Act of 1993
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Religious Freedom and Restoration Act of 1993

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , including

text.#text:
An employer that establishes or maintains a group health plan for its employees (and any covered
			 dependents of such
			 employees) shall not deny coverage of a specific health care item or
			 service with respect to such employees (or dependents) where the coverage
			 of such item or service is required under any provision of Federal law or
			 the regulations promulgated thereunder. A group health plan, as defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, sponsored by an employer, employee organization, or both, and
			 any health insurance coverage, as defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 733(a) of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974/s:733/ss:a

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is required to provide coverage
			 required under the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 2791(b) of the Public
			 Health Service Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, in addition to other applicable
			 requirements.

shall apply notwithstanding any other provision of Federal
			 law, including

may modify such regulations consistent
